section.title: Location-Speakers
section.para: The Western Omo-Tana language, Elmolo was spoken in Kenya on the southeastern shore of Lake Turkana; it is not certain whether there are still any speakers .

biblioset.title: The Non-Bantu Languages of Kenya
biblioset.seriesvolnums: Language and Dialect Atlas of Kenya, vol. 2

section.title: Paradigm Lexemes
section.para:
The following lexical items are used in the verbal paradigms:
The following lexical items are used in the verbal paradigms:
Lemma Gloss Label LexProperties Note
keis
lift up (phonological changes in stem+suff. eriv . p. 196)
keis
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
dekay
hear (dekay ~ dey. phonological changes in stem+suff. deriv. p. 195)
dekay
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
haul
bad
haul
conjClass=stative,final=C,lang=elmolo,pos=verb,statClass=adjective
aw
shoot
aw
conjClass=prefix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
geet
bend (“characteristic of larger number of verbs that have retained part of the suffixial inflections but lost others”)
geet
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
iit
go
iit
conjClass=prefix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
esde
wait (esde ~ este. phonological changes in stem+suff. deriv. p. 195)
esde
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
arg-is
show (from arg ‘see’. phonological changes in stem+suff. deriv. p. 194)
argis
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
li
have (partly employs isolated pronouns of set B)
li
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
ekis
kill
ekis
conjClass=prefix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
apo
good
apo
final=V-non-a,lang=elmolo,pos=verb,statClass=adjective
ekin
swallow
ekin
conjClass=prefix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
ogi
know
ogi
lang=elmolo,pos=verb,statClass=agentlessVerb
arg
see (phonological changes in stem+suff;freq ‘see repeatedly’)
arg
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
kar-is
cook (freq ‘cook repeatedly’)
karis
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
yurg
push (phonological changes in stem+suff. deriv. p 195)
yurg
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
tei
get
tei
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
horr
chase away (retains complete set of pronominal suffixes)
horr
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
nuuk-is
suckle (from nuuk ‘suck’. phonological changes in stem+suff; deriv. p. 194)
nuukis
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
dewe
ask (for final-i/e)
dewe
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
al
stand
al
conjClass=prefix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
kúre-dai
sing (one of verbs with no aspect distinction; imperfect serves also for perfect)
kuredai
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
iif
sleep
iif
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
deera
long
deer
final=a,lang=elmolo,pos=verb,statClass=adjective
wany
big
wany
conjClass=stative,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
ap
have
ap
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
geli
like
geli
lang=elmolo,pos=verb,statClass=agentlessVerb
aac
come
aac
conjClass=prefix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
aam
eat
aam
conjClass=prefix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb
gaapa
short (of people)
gaapa
final=a,lang=elmolo,pos=verb,statClass=adjective
dis
build (“has lost more or less all distinctions of personal suffixes”)
dis
conjClass=suffix,lang=elmolo,pos=verb

inflectionClass: as in all languages, phonological and grammaticization processes conspire to create more or less marked morphophonemic differences in the verbal inflections of different sets of verbs.

section.title: Attested Archive Paradigms
section.para:
The following tabel lists the shared property=value pairs for each paradigm, and then the variable property=value-list (comma separated). The abbreviation "PNG" in the paradigm variable-value lists stnads for:
gender:f,m,⊤ number:pl,sg person:p1,p2,p3
I.e., the PNG combinations normal with finite tam-forms.Clicking on the paradigmLabel will yield a display of the paradigm in question [either by link to hard-coded term cluster, or canned SPARQL query].

table.caption: Table: Prop:Val List of Default Paradigms
